description: Mid 2nd CE villa, bath-suite, and probable timber-shrine. During the late 2nd CE, the site was re-organised, and the shrine rebuilt as a stone Romano-Celtic temple with enclosure wall, this went through further alterations around 280 CE. During the 3rd and 4th CE, the now simple house and agricultural buildings fell into disuse, but the temple may have still been standing beyond 400 CE.
bibliography: Knocker. “Excavations in Collyweston Great Wood, Northamptonshire.” Archaeological Journal 122 (1965).
Martyn, Blick, Brindle, and et al. “Collyweston (Northamptonshire).” The Rural Settlement of Roman Britain: an online resource, 2015. https://doi.org/10.5284/1030449.
“Roman Britain in 1954.” Journal of Roman Studies 45 (1955): 133 ff.
